**Assignment Prompt**

::: notes

This week we come to the end of Section 2 of our class

- The goal for the end of this section is an argument paper selling the reader on the idea that you have a "good" and important research question

<br>

**Remind me, why do we need a research question?**

- **According to Baglione and Huntington-Klein, what does a research question do for your proposal?**

<br>

(A research question **focuses** your work, **drives** your progress and let's you know when you're **done**)

- Baglione (p19):
    
    1. "Topics are too broad" and contain many, many possible issues; Questions focus you on what is manageable 
    2. Questions link you to controversies, controversies lead you to academic literature
    3. Questions demand an answer and the need for an answer helps you move forward and track how far you've gone

- Huntington-Klein:

    1. Exploring data without a question, data mining, can help you find patterns but not help you to understand why things happen
    2. Without a disciplined research question, thereâ€™s no reason not to just check everything! Something is going to pop up as related by random chance if you check enough stuff.

<br>

## "Good" Research Questions {background-image="Images/Background-Rally_v2.png" .center}

<br>

### A good question...

- is interesting, important, controversial, brief, direct, doable and puzzling (Baglione 2019)

- considers potential results, feasibility,  scale and design (Huntington-Klein 2022)

::: notes

Submit a list of TEN clear and distinct reasons you believe this question or topic is important. 

- Remember, premises are ideas supported by evidence, not vice versa 

- Your job is to come up with ten ideas, not ten pieces of evidence supporting a single idea

- Make sure each list includes distinct ideas (with no overlap), AND that each is an idea (not evidence)

## For Next Class: Outline your Paper {background-image="Images/Background-Rally_v2.png" .center .smaller}

**Introduction**

- Set up your argument (e.g. build to your thesis: it is important we answer your RQ)

**Premise 1**

- Explain the idea and connect it to two pieces of evidence

**Premise 2**

- Explain the idea and connect it to two pieces of evidence

**Premise 3**

- Explain the idea and connect it to two pieces of evidence

**Conclusion**

- Wrap it up (e.g. argument restated)

::: notes

For next class I would like each of you to submit an outline of your first paper

- Use bullet points (in complete sentences) to map out the five parts of the paper

- Your job is to communicate the big ideas and the evidence you plan on using to illustrate and support them

<br>

**Questions on the assignment or anything from today?**

<br>

Canvas ASSIGNMENT: Outlining your RQ Paper

Submit a bullet-point outline of your first paper that makes clear:

- You have a complete macro structure (intro, body and conclusion),
- Your introduction sets up the puzzle you are interested in and leads to your RQ as the thesis statement,
- Your meso structure is organized around three big ideas that build logically from one to the next (summarize each premise with a complete sentence or two), and
- Each premise is supported by AT LEAST TWO pieces of evidence (APA citations)

Make sure that each bullet point in your outline is at least one complete sentence. Other people should be able to read your outline and understand the argument in broad strokes.

:::
